misconceptions.name: Reads wrong inputs and hardcodes test value instead of reading 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t) related to a different physics problem and then uses a hardcoded integer 4 for the even-number check instead of reading the 5 integers that need to be processed.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse this average-acceleration code that reads v0, v1, and t, and then just test a hardcoded number (4) for evenness without actually reading the 5 integers the question asks for.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user (typically using nextInt()), and those 5 integers are the ones that should be checked for evenness and summed. No unrelated inputs or hardcoded test values should be used.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Code calls nextDouble() three times instead of nextInt() five times
The only number checked is a hardcoded num = 4
User input does not influence the even-number sum at all
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied or reused code from a different problem (average acceleration) and did not restructure the input logic to match the new requirements. Also shows limited distinction between reading problem-specific inputs and hardcoding test values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the v0, v1, t inputs and instead use a loop that calls input.nextInt() five times, storing each value in a temporary variable and using it in your even check and sum.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard with Scanner
Mapping problem requirements to input variables
Avoiding hardcoded test data in final solutions
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and variables (v0, v1, t) clearly belong to a different problem, and the only potentially relevant value (num = 4) is hardcoded rather than read.

evidence.note: Reads three doubles for v0, v1, t and then uses a hardcoded num = 4 instead of reading 5 integers from the user.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process the 5 required inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to handle the 5 integers. It processes only a single hardcoded number instead of iterating over multiple user-provided values.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can just handle one number (or a fixed case) without using a loop, even though the problem talks about 5 integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Because the problem specifies 5 integers, the program should use a loop (for or while) that runs exactly 5 times. Each iteration should read one integer, check if it is even, and update the sum if needed.
symptoms: No for or while loop present in the code
Only a single variable num is checked for evenness
Variables sum and count are defined but not used in any iteration structure
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding or omission of the need to repeat the same logic for multiple inputs; possibly thinking the requirement could be met without iteration.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop like `for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)` that, in each iteration, reads an integer, checks if it is even, and conditionally adds it to `sum`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop structure at all and only a single number is processed; the rubric explicitly requires processing 5 inputs.

evidence.note: Processes a single hardcoded num without any loop; no iterative structure is present to handle 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of if-statement scope without braces
misconceptions.description: The student writes an if statement without braces and appears to intend that both sum and count are updated only when the number is even, but in Java only the first statement is actually controlled by the if.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I put two indented lines after an if without braces, both lines will be executed only when the condition is true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an if without braces controls only the very next statement. To execute multiple statements conditionally, you must enclose them in `{}`. Indentation alone has no effect on control flow.
symptoms: if is written without braces but followed by two indented lines
Only `sum += num;` is actually conditional; `count++;` always executes
Pattern suggests an intention to make both updates conditional
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between languages where indentation defines blocks and Java's syntax, or general misunderstanding that indentation in Java does not affect which statements are part of the if.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Whenever you want more than one statement to run inside an if, always use braces: `if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; count++; }`.
related_concepts: Use of braces to define blocks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The formatting strongly implies both lines were meant to be inside the if, even though only the first is; however, `count` is unused, so this may be partially incomplete code.

evidence.note: Without braces, only `sum += num;` is controlled by the if; `count++;` always runs, which contradicts the likely intended block structure suggested by indentation.

misconceptions.name: Does not print or fully use the computed sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program initializes a sum accumulator and conditionally adds one value to it, but never prints the sum and never uses the count to manage the required 5 inputs or any output.
misconceptions.student_belief: Defining and updating `sum` is enough, even if the program never outputs the final result, and it's not necessary to complete the full accumulation over the specified inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must both compute the sum of the even numbers from the 5 inputs and print the final sum in the required format (e.g., `Sum of even numbers: 14`). Any accumulator variable should be meaningfully updated and then used in the final output.
symptoms: sum is initialized and potentially updated but never printed
count is initialized and incremented but never used
No output line corresponding to 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
Final program behavior is only to print average acceleration, unrelated to the required result
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation of the problem requirements; the student set up some variables for accumulation but did not follow through to produce the required final output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After processing all 5 integers in a loop, add a `System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);` line so the user can see the computed result.
related_concepts: Using variables meaningfully instead of leaving them unused
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no print statement for `sum` or any mention of even-number sum in the output, and `count` is unused, indicating an incomplete or incorrect finalization of the algorithm.

evidence.note: The only printed output is the average acceleration; `sum` and `count` are never printed or otherwise used to show the result of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reading Unrelated Input and Wrong Data Type
misconceptions.description: The student included code to read three `double` values (`v0`, `v1`, `t`) related to an acceleration problem, which is entirely irrelevant to this task. Furthermore, they used `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`, indicating confusion about required data types and problem scope adherence.
misconceptions.student_belief: The structure for reading input from a previous problem can be reused, and the input requirements (data type and quantity) are flexible or interchangeable.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must strictly adhere to the requirements: reading exactly 5 integers (`input.nextInt()`) for this specific problem.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t'
Variables are declared as `double`
The subsequent sum logic uses hardcoded values instead of these inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: Copy-paste error from unrelated work combined with a failure to critically analyze the problem's strict input requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always ensure the type and quantity of inputs match the problem statement. Use `Scanner.nextInt()` for integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence due to the explicit presence of code related to 'v0, v1, and t' and the use of the double type.

evidence.note: The submission reads entirely wrong variables and data types (`double` instead of 5 `int`s).

misconceptions.name: Missing Iteration for Multiple Inputs
misconceptions.description: The student failed to implement any loop structure (for/while) to process the required 5 integers. Instead, they hardcoded a single value (`int num = 4;`) and applied the logic only once, demonstrating a critical failure to use iteration for repetitive tasks.
misconceptions.student_belief: Input values can be represented or tested by a single hardcoded example, and loops are not necessary to process multiple, distinct user inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A loop must be used to iterate 5 times, calling `input.nextInt()` inside the loop to read and process each of the user's intended values.
symptoms: No `for` or `while` loops present
Input source is hardcoded
The core logic runs exactly once
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of how iteration constructs (loops) are fundamental to processing sequential or repeated inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how to use a `for` loop to repeat an action (reading input and checking parity) a fixed number of times (5 times).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly initializes a single number variable and runs the check once, with absolutely no loop structure present.

evidence.note: Shows hardcoding of 'num' and a single conditional check, replacing the required 5-iteration loop.

misconceptions.name: Missing Final Output Statement
misconceptions.description: The program initializes and updates the sum (for the single hardcoded value), but entirely neglects to print the final result to the console, making it impossible to verify the output.
misconceptions.student_belief: Calculation is the primary goal, and printing the result is a secondary or forgotten step.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The final accumulated value must be printed using a statement like `System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);`
symptoms: No `System.out.print` or `System.out.printf` after the calculation block
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete solution development or overlooking final requirements after implementing the core logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always ensure the final answer is displayed to the user according to the sample run format.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The last line of the main method is a calculation (`count++;`), and there is no subsequent output command.

evidence.note: The logic ends and the main method closes without any statement to print the computed sum.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of if-statement block scoping (missing braces)
misconceptions.description: The student writes an if statement without braces and indents two lines under it, suggesting they believe both sum += num and count++ are controlled by the if, but in Java only the first statement is actually part of the if body.
misconceptions.student_belief: Indentation determines which statements are controlled by an if in Java, so writing two indented lines after if (num % 2 == 0) means both will only run when num is even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an if statement without braces controls only the very next statement. To execute multiple statements conditionally, they must be enclosed in curly braces { }.
symptoms: if (num % 2 == 0) has no braces, yet two lines are visually grouped under it.
count++ will execute regardless of whether num is even, which is unlikely to be the student's intent.
The structure suggests confusion between visual indentation and actual Java block semantics.
misconceptions.root_cause: Overgeneralizing from languages or pseudocode where indentation defines scope, or not fully internalizing Java's requirement for braces to group multiple statements under a conditional.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Whenever more than one statement should run conditionally, always wrap them inside braces: if (condition) { ... }.
related_concepts: Difference between formatting and control flow
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The stylistic indentation strongly implies the student wanted both lines inside the if even though Java will only conditionally execute the first; this is a common beginner confusion.

evidence.note: No braces are used; due to Java's rules, only sum += num is conditional but indentation suggests the student assumes both lines are inside the if.
